th
 of January, after making the updates to Sarah’s salary and the tech subsidy. 
 
Also, you are still on a separate pay run, receiving only the tech subsidy. You can remove the tech subsidy for yourself so that you are not seeing multiple pay runs to process/approve.  (and eventually, you’ll need to get back on the normal pay run, when the time comes – not a separate payroll).
 
Thx,
R

subject: Declined: LCW x Eventbrite Report Preview
body: Hey, I’m flying back from Brazil and not getting home until probably 12pm that day (if all goes well with the flights)…but if I can help with the analysis before, I’m happy to.

subject: FW: Updated payment plan
body:
Hi Alisa,
Just confirming, per our conversation on whatsapp, that the payment plan structure is indeed OK as we discussed and can therefore be entered into Quickbooks with the related accrued interest. Again, the payment amounts and start date are mostly irrelevant, given your cash situation and the bank’s subordination (although that doesn’t really apply to reconciliations – whether they like that fact or not)…but the format for accruing is helpful to have documented.
 
It might be best to enter them as a lump sum in Oct (for everything up through October) and then monthly for the correct amounts (so that we don’t change any Q1-Q3 numbers on your balance sheet) so that they are true reflection of balances.
 
Then, we can use this spreadsheet to track payments when the time comes – including for the  $5k from reconciliations currently being paid monthly to Monica and me for our assistance. (For those payments, btw, I think it makes the most sense to enter them directly as checks/payments without an “invoice” or bill from us – to avoid confusion. They should be reducing the reconciliations balance due…not paying an expense.)
 
Sarah can make the entries for 2023, with your confirmation.
Thx,
R
 
 
From:
 Randall Stieghorst 
Sent:
 Tuesday, August 22, 2023 10:44
To:
 Alisa Kolodizner <a.kolodizner@lcwmail.com>
Cc:
 Jennifer Barbieri <j.barbieri@lcwmail.com>; Antonio Jones <a.jones@lcwmail.com>; Monica Marcel <monica.marcel.2012@gmail.com>; Chuck Adams <c.adams@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 Updated payment plan
 
Hey Alisa,
In light of the current cash situation (and the bank’s subordination letter), I’ve updated the payment plan to push any and all payments out to March 2024. Although I realize that the payment amounts themselves are probably unrealistic (because they are squished into the original timeline we had in the spreadsheet), it at least gives a running tally of where things are.  I’ve also tweaked the spreadsheet to include more rows (for clarity), showing EOM balances, interest payment amounts, etc.). If you compare the May and Aug tabs, you’ll see what I mean.
 
Although the only changes are to the timing of possible payments, please confirm that we are in agreement on the structure of the payment plan. And once confirmed, it would be a good idea to ensure that the balance sheet shows the correct amount due for the notes – especially for the reconciliation amount (which is just the A/R from the original sales agreement – but now with accruing interest).
 
If there are any questions or you want to chat through things, let me know – otherwise, just a confirmation that this is correct and reflects our mutual understanding is sufficient.
 
Thx,
R
 
 
Randall Stieghorst
LCW

subject: Fwd: Webinar: Revenue Forecasting for a Profitable Year Ahead
body:
Fyi. 
From:
 Team Scoro <marketing@scoro.com>
Sent:
 Thursday, January 18, 2024 4:02:39 PM
To:
 Randall Stieghorst <r.stieghorst@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 Webinar: Revenue Forecasting for a Profitable Year Ahead
 
 
You don't often get email from marketing@scoro.com. 
Learn why this is important
Join our webinar and uncover practical tips on reliable Revenue Forecasting.
 
 
Hey Randall,
 
Creating a 
reliable revenue forecast 
can be tough. Uncertainties in the sales pipeline, project scopes, timelines, and market conditions make it challenging. 
 
The result? You have either given up on forecasting revenue, or it takes a lot of manual effort. 
 
You can never be sure if you have enough work and revenue lined up for the coming months. 
 
To help you navigate this complexity, we are hosting a 
webinar
 on 
revenue forecasting best practices
. 
 
Our hosts, Helen and Sander, will give you practical advice on:
Creating a robust forecasting framework
Avoiding common forecasting pitfalls
Maintaining a realistic forecast throughout the year
The live Zoom webinar is on 
January 31st at 3:00 PM GMT / 10:00 AM EST
.
 
P.S. Can’t join us live?
 Register anyway, and we’ll send you a recording after the event.
We look forward to seeing you at the webinar! 
 
Best wishes,
Team Scoro
Register now!
 
 
 
 
 
Scoro Software, 81 Rivington Street, London, England EC2A 3AY, United Kingdom 
Unsubscribe
 
Manage preferences
 
We are notifying you that we are processing your data based on legitimate interest (EU regulation 2016/679 (GDPR) Art 6 (1) (f)) as we have acquired your business contacts as you were a trialist user of Scoro or have requested a Scoro demo. You have under GDPR the right to opt-out and object against us processing your data under that ground. For more information about how we process data, please see our 
Privacy Policy
.

Done – and I did the same for an overpayment from Ralph Lauren of $20,500 received on 6/6/23.
 
From:
 Randall Stieghorst <r.stieghorst@lcwmail.com> 
Sent:
 Saturday, January 13, 2024 07:07
To:
 Sarah Gluckstein <s.gluckstein@lcwmail.com>; Accounting <accounting@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 Diligent overpayment
 
In my opinion, we should generate a prepayment invoice for Diligent (dated 1/1/23) and pay it with this payment. That will get it into Scoro too – and it will show as a prepayment rather than a negative accounts receivable (which is just weird – and never seems to get applied!)
Thoughts?
-R
 
 
Randall Stieghorst

subject: Re: Important: Verify Your Tax Documents by January 23rd
body:
I'm fairly certain that's it.  Somewhere in QB is the 1099 mapping... and we can just add the sales and marketing account. (And make sure all her bills are charged to the same account. 
From:
 Accounting <accounting@lcwmail.com>
Sent:
 Wednesday, January 17, 2024 3:20:54 PM
To:
 Briza Cardenas <b.cardenas@lcwmail.com>; Randall Stieghorst <r.stieghorst@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 RE: Important: Verify Your Tax Documents by January 23rd
 
 
Briza,
 
I’m not sure why the 1099 is only showing $10,000, I checked in QBO and we show all the bill payments that she indicated (see attached report). Could the issue be that the Sales & Marketing account isn’t mapped to report 1099? We could change those bills to map to the same payroll sub-account as the others and see what happens.
 
SG
 
From:
 Briza Cardenas <b.cardenas@lcwmail.com> 
Sent:
 Tuesday, January 16, 2024 14:44
To:
 Accounting <accounting@lcwmail.com>; Sarah Gluckstein <s.gluckstein@lcwmail.com>; Randall Stieghorst <r.stieghorst@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 FW: Important: Verify Your Tax Documents by January 23rd
 
Good afternoon,
 
Deb responded to my note below regarding the 1099 doc that QBO creates for e-filing. She said it is incorrect. Can someone go into QBO and see what’s going on with her vendor account?
 
I attached the doc I sent her, and her W9. 
 
Briza Cardenas  
(she/her)
Chief of Staff, Office of the CEO
LCW

b.cardenas@lcwmail.com

Subject:
 Re: Important: Verify Your Tax Documents by January 23rd
 
Briza
This is incorrect. 
I have been working with LCW since April and have have been paid $37000 of the $47000 I am owed as part of my original contracts
I received the following payments in 2023:
June 7, 2023 = $7,000 (April invoice)
Aug 1, 2023 = $10000 (May Invoice)
Aug 28, 2023 = $10000 (June invoice)
Dec 7, 2023 = $10000 (July invoice)
For a total of $37000 paid to me, recipient in 2023. (Not $10000)
Note. My August invoice of $10000 has not been paid.  and I am not billing for work done in Sept and October.
Thanks
deb
 
 
 
 
 
On 2024-01-16 14:46, Briza Cardenas wrote:
Good Afternoon Deb,
 
I hope this email finds you well. As we approach the tax season, we want to ensure that all necessary documentation is accurate and up-to-date. In accordance with IRS regulations, we kindly request you to verify your tax documents 
before January 23rd.
 
Please review the attached details to confirm their accuracy.
 
If you identify any discrepancies or if there are updates needed, please reach out 
no later than January 23rd
. This will allow us enough time to address any issues and ensure that your tax documents are correct to e-file at the end of the month.
 
Your cooperation in this matter is highly appreciated, as it helps us maintain compliance with tax regulations and facilitates a smooth tax-filing process for both parties.
 
Thank you,
 
Briza Cardenas  
(she/her)
Chief of Staff, Office of the CEO
LCW
